questions.text: Which of the following parts of the retina are correctly marked?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer, 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer

options.label: B
options.text: 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer

questions.correct_answer: A. 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer, 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer, 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer first always look for nuclear layer(blue coloured) and photoreceptor layer . than identify inner limiting membrane. Than nuclear layer in centre towards inner limiting layer is plexiform layer

questions.text: Which of the following is true about macular opacity?

options.label: D
options.text: Iris and pupillary margin are not visible

questions.correct_answer: B. Only pupillary margin is visible
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only pupillary margin is visible Only pupillary margin is visible in macular opacity pupillary margin is visible and iris structural details are not visible.

Highyeild:

TYPES PUPILLARY MARGIN IRIS STRUCTURAL DETAILS Nebular ( Faint ) Visible Visible Macular Visible Not Visible Leukomatous ( Dense / Completely White ) Not Visible Not Visible

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Iris And Pupil Is Visible :- These Are Visible In Nebular Option: C. Iris Details Are Visible :- Iris Is Visible Only In Nebular Type Of Corneal Opacity Option: D. Iris And Pupillary Margin Not Visible :- Both The Margin Are Not Visible In Leukomatous (Dense /Completely White )

Table:

#MANTRA the maximum visual disturbance or distortion is caused in nebular type:

questions.text: A factory worker presented with a history of chuna falling in both his eyes few hours back. What is the first immediate management?

options.label: C
options.text: Check vision in both the eyes

options.label: D
options.text: Check IOP and plan for surgery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Copious irrigation of eyes The immediate step after trauma to eye with chemical injury should be copious irrigation of eyes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The first immediate step should be irrigation of the eye. history should be taken after irrigation of the eye Option: C. After irrigation of the eye history should be taken, and then we should look for the vision in both the eyes Option: D. after irrigation of the eyes if still burning persists and there is difficulty in vision next step is to check IOP and plan for Surgery to remove the substance from the eye.

questions.text: A 6 month old baby, born preterm at 33 weeks of gestation, is brought by parents with complaints of white pupillary reflex since 2 weeks. CT revealed calcification of the globe in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retinoblastoma Retinoblastoma (RB) gene has been identified as 14 band on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q 14) and is a 'cancer suppressor' or 'antioncogenic' gene. Deletion or inactivation of both the normal allels of this protective gene by two mutations (Knudson's two hit hypothesis, 1971) results in occurrence of retinoblastoma Leukocoria or yellowish-white pupillary reflex (also called as amaurotic cat's eye appearance) is the commonest presenting feature

Highyeild:

Differential diagnosis of leukocoria. Various conditions other than retinoblastoma, which present as leukocoria are collectively called as 'pseudoglioma. A few common conditions are congenital cataract, inflammatory deposits in vitreous following a plastic cyclitis or choroiditis, coloboma of the choroid, the retrolental fibroplasia (retinopathy of prematurity), persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous, toxocara endophthalmitis and exudative retinopathy of Coats.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. ROP:- Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a bilateral proliferative retinopathy, occurring in premature infants with low birth weight who often have been exposed to high concentration of oxygen. Earlier this disease was known as retrolental fibroplasia. Option: C Glaucoma:- Lacrimation, photophobia and blepharospasm often occur together and form the classic triad of symptoms of congenital glaucoma. Option: D. Congenital Cataract:- it has white central opacity . impairing vision but does not lead to white pupillary reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form the inner component of photoreceptors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Membranous Disc The inner segment of a photoreceptor also contains: Ribosomes, Membranes where opsin molecules are assembled, Golgi apparatus, and Endoplasmic reticulum

Highyeild:

Ultrathin sections viewed in an electron microscope . The photoreceptor consists of An outer segment, filled with stacks of membranes (like a stack of poker chips) containing the visual pigment molecules such as rhodopsins, An inner segment containing mitochondria, ribosomes and membranes where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment discs, A cell body containing the nucleus of the photoreceptor cell and A synaptic terminal where neurotransmission to second order neurons occurs.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. mitochondria form the inner segment of the of the photoreceptor Option: C. golgi apparatus is present between external limiting membrane and outer segment portion of rods and cones Option: D. endoplasmic reticulum is present between external limiting membrane and outer segment portion of rods and cones

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tractional retinal detachment Tractional retinal detachment most common cause is diabetic retinopathy. Occurs due to static vitero retinal traction. Causes: retinopathy of prematurity. penetrating trauma sickle cell retinopathy Can you go to there is no clinical features break no photopsia no floaters occurs due to static with retinal traction. loss of vision that is gradual and painless. detached retina is concave in shape.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Posterior Staphyloma:- it is due to ectasia of sclera at posterior pole may be apparent as an excavation with vessels bending backwards over its margin Option: B. Retinoschisis:- The term retinoschisis refers to splitting of the sensory retina into two layers at the level of the inner nuclear and outer plexiform layers. Option: D. Progressive Myopia:- progressive myopia is: (i) familial; (ii) more common elongation of the eyeball mainly in certain races like Chinese, Japanese, Arabs and pole and surrounding area; Jews, iii) uncommon among Negroes, Nubians and anterior to the equator may be Sudanese and (iv) more common in women than men. Autosomal dominant pathological myopia has been linked to genes 18p11.31 and 12q21.23.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of bilateral sudden painless loss of vision?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetic retinopathy Risk Factor: Age of onset of diabetes also act as a risk factor. The risk of retinopathy in a child with onset of diabetes at the age of 2 years is negligible for the first 10 years. Incidence is more in females than males (4:3). Poor metabolic control is less important than duration, but is nevertheless relevant to the development and progression of DR. Clinical Features: Microaneurysms hemorrhage flame shaped and dot pand blot cotton wool spot Venous beading or looping

Highyeild:

Duration of diabetes is the most important determining factor. After 10 years, 20% of type I and 25% of type II diabetics develop retinopathy. Alter 20 years, 90% of type I and 60% of type II diabetics develop retinopathy, After 30 years, 95% of both type 1 and type H diabetics develop retinopathy,

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Acute Congestive Glaucoma :- Ut causes sudden painful loss of vision Option: C. Keratoconus:- Patient presents with defective patient due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism, which does not improve fully despite full correction with glasses Option: D Iridocyclitis:- It causes gradual painful defective vision

Table:

#MANTRA Sudden painless loss of vision Central retinal artery occlusion Massive vitreous haemorrhage Retinal detachment involving macular area Ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion Sudden painless onset of defective vision Central serous retinopathy Optic neuritis Methyl alcohol amblyopia Nonischemic central retinal vein occlusion Sudden painful loss of vision Acute congestive glaucoma’s (primary or secondary) Acute iridocyclitis Chemical injuries to the eyeball Mechanical injuries to the eyeball Gradual painless defective vision Progressive pterygium involving papillary area Corneal degenerations Corneal dystrophies Developmental cataract Senile cataract Chorioretinal degeneration Age-related macular degeneration Diabetic retinopathy Refractive errors Gradual painful defective vision Chronic iridocyclitis Corneal ulceration Chronic simple glaucoma Transient loss of vision (Amaurosis fugax) Carotid artery disease Papilloedema Giant cell arteritis Migraine Raynaud's disease Severe hypertension Prodromal symptom of CRAO

questions.text: In FFA, the microaneurysm appear as:

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperfluorescent branching like structure in the vessel

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperfluorescent dots Microaneurysms are seen as multiple tiny dot-like dilatations along the venous end of capillaries. They are commonly found in diabetic retinopathy. Other causes include hypertensive retinopathy, retinal vein occlusions, Bales' disease and sickle cell microaneurysm appear as hyperfluorescent dots

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It can indicate compromised blood flow to retinal Option: C. It is due to blockage and filling defect Option: D. It is due to serpiginous choroiditis

Solution:

Astigmatism Defective vision occurs when it encroaches the pupillary area or due to corneal astigmatism induced by fibrosis in the regressive stage .

Highyeild:

Pterygium: Pterygium (L. Pterygion = a wing) is a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from either side within the interpalpebral fissure. pterygium is a degenerative and hyperplastic condition of conjunctiva. The subconjunctival tissue undergoes elastotic degeneration and proliferates as vascularised granulation tissue under the epithelium, which ultimately encroaches the cornea. The corneal epithelium, Bowman's layer and superficial stroma are destroyed. Clinical Features: Age: Usually seen in old age. Sex: More common in males doing outdoor work than females. Laterality: It may be unilateral or bilateral. Usually present on the nasal side but may also occur on the temporal side. Symptoms: Cosmetic intolerance may be the only issue in otherwise asymptomatic condition in early stages. Foreign body sensation and irritation may be experienced. Defective vision occurs when it encroaches the pupillary area or due to corneal astigmatism induced by fibrosis in the regressive stage. Diplopia may occur occasionally due to limitation of ocular movements. Complications Cystic degeneration and infection are infrequent. Neoplastic change to epithelioma, fibrosarcoma or malignant melanoma, may occur rarely.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Eye Pain:- It is a degenerative disorder hence does not cause eye pain. Foreign body sensation and irritation may be experienced. Option: B. Macular Edema:- Pterygium does not cause macular edema Option: C. Purulent Discharge:- It is a degenerative condition . and causer stocker’s line does not cause purulent discharge .

questions.text: In case of Best disease, which of the following is the diagnostic investigation:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

EOG Since the EOG reflects the presynaptic function of the retina, any disease that interferes with the functional interplay between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and the photoreceptors. EOG serves as a test that is supplementary and complementary to ERG and in certain states is more sensitive than the ERG, e.g. in diagnosis of Best's disease,

Highyeild:

Best's disease: Inheritence: Autosomal dominant Clinical picture can be divided into five stages: Pre-vitelliform stage. Normal fundus, but EOG is abnormal. Vitelliform stage. Egg yolk lesion at macula. Pseudo hypopyon stage. Partially absorbed egg yolk lesion. Vitelli eruptive stage. A scrambled egg appearance of macula. Stage of scarring. Hypertrophic or atrophic vascularized scar at macula.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. ERG:- ERG is very useful in detecting functional abnormalities of the outer retina (up to bipolar cell layer), much before the ophthalmoscopic signs appear. However, ERG is normal in diseases involving ganglion cells and the higher visual pathway, such as optic atrophy. Option: C. Multifocal Erg:- in case of best disease ERG. is supplementary to EOG . Option: D. Visual Evoked Potential:- In the lesions affecting the conduction of the nerve impulse by visual pathway (e.g. retrobulbar neuritis) the amplitude is reduced and there is delay in the transmission time. The timing of the response is more reliable than the amplitude. Increased latency is also common in macular dysfunction; therefore, a delayed VEP should not be considered pathognomonic of optic nerve disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about viscoelastic substance?

options.label: A
options.text: Cause mechanical injury to corneal endothelium

options.label: B
options.text: Prevents Anterior Chamber from collapsing during crucial steps like Capsulorrhexis and IOL placement.

options.label: C
options.text: It is inert and can be left behind after surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Silicone oil, perfluoropropane and sodium hexafluoride are most commonly used substance

questions.correct_answer: B. Prevents Anterior Chamber from collapsing during crucial steps like Capsulorrhexis and IOL placement.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prevents Anterior Chamber from collapsing during crucial steps like Capsulorrhexis and IOL placement. Viscosity of the substances should be enough to provide sufficient space for manipulation within the eye. Protectability and maintenance of space. It should protect the endothelium, separate the tissues, maintain the space and act as a lubricant

Highyeild:

Use of viscous or viscoelastic substances has become almost mandatory in the modern microphthalmic surgery, especially intraocular lens implantation, which involves a risk of involuntary tissue damage due to intraocular manipulations. Properties of viscoelastic substances An ideal viscoelastic substance should have the following properties: Chemically, the material should be inert Optically clear. Viscosity of the substances should be enough to provide sufficient space for manipulation within the eye. Hydrophilic and dilutable properties are necessary to irrigate the material out of the eye after the operation. Protectability and maintenance of space. It should protect the endothelium, separate the tissues, maintain the space and act as a lubricant.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It does not cause injury to corneal endothelium it is used to protect corneal endothelium. Option: C. Postoperative rise in intraocular pressure may occur if a considerable amount of viscoelastic substance is left inside the anterior chamber; so it must be washed off after surgery. Option: D. methylcellulose is the most commonly used substance .
